turns.speaker: WENDOVER
turns.text: See what?

turns.speaker: SIR IAN
turns.text: The pattern.  Each incident occurred almost precisely a thousand statute miles from the Pole.  A line through the points of occurrence makes almost a complete circle...

turns.speaker: WENDOVER
turns.text: Well, I'll be - !

turns.speaker: SIR IAN
turns.text: I'll be another!

turns.speaker: SIR IAN
turns.text: Just musing about our 'one-eyed adversary' and the legend of Homer.  'Cyclopes' were the Sons of Heaven, who forged the thunder- bolts thrown by Zeus.

turns.speaker: WENDOVER
turns.text: Our 'Cyclops' throws quite a thunderbolt, itself!

turns.speaker: WENDOVER
turns.text: You plotted the course of Cyclops?  Then that's <u>our</u> course!  Wherever <u>he</u> goes, <u>we</u> go.....until we get him!

turns.speaker: SIR IAN
turns.text: Or, perhaps, until he gets us?

turns.speaker: SIR IAN
turns.text: We've asked ourselves that - over and over - a thousand times.

turns.speaker: WENDOVER
turns.text: But <u>answers</u> are what we need - not more questions!

turns.speaker: WENDOVER
turns.text: Due north.  At five knots...no, six!

turns.speaker: SIR IAN
turns.text: Toward the Pole!

turns.speaker: SIR IAN
turns.text: Cyclops will have to linger at the Pole to recharge his power banks.

turns.speaker: WENDOVER
turns.text: All right - go to it.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You got yourself a computer, Alma.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Been putting my files into it. You take sugar and milk?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: No. Black.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Are you alright, Wade?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah, sure. Why? I got this damned tooth, I got a few things bugging me, like everybody else. But I'm okay.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Well, you look... sad. Upset. I don't mean to pry. I'm sorry about your mother. It was a nice funeral.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Alma, I think there's some dirty business going on in this town.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Always has been.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: This is maybe worse than you and I are used to.  What I'm talking about, I'm talking about murder. Among other things.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Evan Twombley, the union boss who got shot. Somebody murdered him.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You know Jack Hewitt, the kid I work with?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: ...if Jack told the truth, he could be free by the time he's my age.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Sometimes things are simpler than you think. Let me ask you a question.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You don't believe me?

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: About Jack? No. Have you checked out the tax bill on your father's farm lately?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I know he's due for the last two years. I was thinking of paying it when the insurance comes in.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: Has anybody offered to buy it?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: As a mater of fact, yes. LaRiviere.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: This is from three years ago. Some difference, huh?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What is the Northcountry Development Association?

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: I went down to Concord to check it out. The president is Mel Gordon. The vice-president and treasurer is Gordon LaRiviere. Those boys are buying up the mountain, Wade. $364,000 this year. I believe that's out of LaRiviere's league.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Twombley involved?

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: He musta found out. They had to get rid of him. And Jack'll get blamed.

turns.speaker: ALMA
turns.text: All the figures show is that Gordon LaRiviere is going to be a very rich man using his position as Selectman. In a year or two, you won't recognize this town.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What are you boys up to?

turns.speaker: CHICK
turns.text: Same old shit.

turns.speaker: CHICK
turns.text: The good news is we haven't got to your car yet. The bad news --

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Just tell me when you'll have it fixed.

turns.speaker: CHICK
turns.text: -- the bad news is there's a problem with Gordon's truck what somebody drove through the ice last night. Figured you'd know something about that, Wade.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah. I know about that.

turns.speaker: CHICK
turns.text: LaRiviere says he ain't gonna pay for the fixin' of your car. A couple hundred for the clutch. I got some more bad news. Wanna hear it?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: CHICK
turns.text: Chub says you're fired.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: He can't fire me. LaRiviere already did that this morning.

turns.speaker: CHICK
turns.text: He's a Selectman. The town. He said to tell you to turn your badge in and clean out your office. I'm supposed to pull the CB and police light out of your car. They're town property.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I screwed up the divorce. I agreed with everything she said. I wanted her to like me. I just want to be a good father.

turns.speaker: HAND
turns.text: It would help if you were married, if there was someone at home while you work.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I plan to. Soon.

turns.speaker: HAND
turns.text: How soon?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: This spring.

turns.speaker: HAND
turns.text: Good. It would help if there were some drug or alcohol abuse on the part of your ex-wife. Sexual problems upsetting to the child.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It looks pretty hopeless, don't it?

turns.speaker: HAND
turns.text: No, not exactly. I'll look at the divorce decree, see if we can get it redrawn. Interview your daughter. Jill, right?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAND
turns.text: Fine. I'll need a $500 retainer. You can mail it.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Jesus. How much... how much will the whole thing cost?

turns.speaker: HAND
turns.text: Hard to say. If we go for custody, depositions, psychiatric evaluations, it could drag on. Ten or twelve thousand dollars. She could win on appeal. If we just want to get the visitation rights redrawn, assuming they're unduly restrictive, it wouldn't be more than twenty-five hundred.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: HAND
turns.text: You might be better off legally as well as financially to just go for the --

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah. I know. The custody suit thing was just my getting back at her. I'm not as dumb as I look. Whatever you say. I love my daughter.  I'll send you the five hundred.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You heard the news.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: I hear Twombley got shot.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: You see it?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Nope. Heard it. We wasn't far apart. I spotted this buck, then I heard the gun go off and Twombley was gone. I looked over the little cliff we was using for a stand and there the fucker was, deader'n shit. Called it right in.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: This is gonna be one fucking mess to clean up. Twombley's son-in-law and daughter are up the weekend. Didn't you say you'd seen him, Wade?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Might as well take the rest of the day off. You look sort of fucked up. You've been paid for the day, anyhow, right?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Not exactly. I mean, he never paid me.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: You'll get your money. Don't talk to any newspapers about this. Twombley's a big deal down in Massachusetts, you know. Tell them your lawyer says you shouldn't comment.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Lawyer? I don't need no lawyer, do I?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: No, of course not. Just say it, that's all.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: He's on to us!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Shit! What are we gonna do?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Maybe I can buy him off. I gotta talk to Mel.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You can't buy Wade off.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: We bought you.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: That was me.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: It's not enough snow, not for tracking the bastards. No advantage there, kid.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Don't worry, Mr. Twombley, I know where those suckers are. Rain or shine, snow or no snow. I know deer. We'll kill us a buck today. Guaranteed. Before ten.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Guaranteed, eh?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yep. Right about now the does are holing up in the brush piles. The bucks are right behind them and we're right behind the bucks.  This gun gets fired before ten o'clock. Whether it kills a deer or not is more less up to you. I'll put you inside 30, 35 yards of a buck the first four hours of the season. That's what you're paying me for, ain't it?

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Damn straight!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Done much shooting with that rifle yet?

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Tell you what. You get me close to a big buck by ten, kid, there's another hundred bucks in it.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: If you get it?

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You might not kill it.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: You think so.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You might gut-shoot it or cripple it for somebody else to find and tag. Can't guarantee that won't happen, especially with a new gun. I may have to shoot it.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: You take care of your end, kid, I'll take care of mine.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Mmm.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: You understand what I'm saying? I want a deer, a dead one, not a cripple or whatthefuck.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I get it.  No sweat. You'll get yourself a deer and you'll get him dead. And you'll have him by coffee time.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: And you'll get your extra hundred bucks.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Wonderful!

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: I'm okay.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Follow close. We'll cross the next meadow.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I used to play ball.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Drafted by the Red Sox.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: You played for the Sox?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Double A. New Britain.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Pitcher. "Best ballplayer to come out of New Hampshire since Carlton Fisk."

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: They said.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Hmm.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: The only difference between me and that Clemens on TV is luck, shit luck.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Ruined my arm. Brought me along too fast. Why'd it have to be my fucking arm, I used to think. Then I realized it had to be somebody's fucking arm.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Safety on?

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: This way.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: Sun's gettin high.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Deers have ears too.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Fresh tracks.  Deer shit. Big one. Here's your buck, Mr. Twombley. I'll circle around.

turns.speaker: TWOMBLEY
turns.text: You only got a little while if you want your hundred bucks.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Don't mind if I do.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: LaRiviere's having a hell of a time in there. Master of fucking ceremonies.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Where's that gun you were bragging on today?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No brag. Just fact.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Got you for -- 450, 500 bucks?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I thought I told you to move that truck!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Relax, Chief. We're leaving. You wanna toke?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You gotta be more careful about that shit. Gordon or one of those guys sees you smoking that wacky tabacky around me they'll expect me to bust you. And I'll be outta a job.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Some job. Here, have a hit. Don't be such a hardass. I know you got problems, but everybody's got problems.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Not here.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Got a job first thing in the morning, first day of season. Saturday I'll hunt for myself. Twombley something. - Er --

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Evan. He's a mucky-muck union official from Massachusetts. You're lucky.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Don't know about lucky. The guy's a full-blown asshole. Pay's good, though. $100 a day. I got to guarantee a kill, of course. Which I can do. There's some monster bucks hiding out up there.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: How'd you get the job?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Gordon, he's always got some angle working. He wants to keep Twombley happy, I'm his boy.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Like you and Gordon?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Right. The sonofabitch couldn't get along without me.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah, he'd go broke tomorrow if you quit him.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Right!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Bastard's got his high beams on.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Shit.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Aw, shit, she's here to get Jill. Me and Jill had a little argument. Jack, I got to get back, get back to town. Move this thing, will you? See if you can get back to the Town Hall before they get there, okay?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Piece of fucking cake.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Where'd Twombley get shot?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: In the chest.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: No, I mean whereabouts.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: A half mile in, along the old lumber road.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You bring him up yourself? That's a steep climb.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: The ambulance guys lugged him up.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You stayed away?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Where'd you get the blood?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What blood?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: On your sleeve.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Musta... How'd I know? What're you doing, playing cop?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I gotta make a report to Fish and Game. I was just wondering, that's all. What'd he do, to shoot himself, I mean?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Who the fuck knows? Musta slipped or something. I just heard the gun go off.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I never seen a man shot before. Not even in the service. Must be something.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Well, I didn't actually see him do it. Like I said.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Sure you did.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Saw him do it?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What the fuck you telling me, Wade? I never seen the guy get shot, I told you that.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You musta seen him get shot. I know you did.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Let's get the fuck outta here. You're not making any sense, man.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: There's your old twenty-gauge, and that there's the new Browning you was showing me last night. This must be Twombley's gun. Brand new. Very fancy tooling. Probably fired one time. It's a beautiful piece of work.  But what the hell, Jack, I guess you deserve it. Right's right.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Twombley sure as hell won't be shooting it again.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He sure as hell won't.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm fucking out of here.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Lawford?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Out of this fucking job. This job sucks. Working outside in the winter sucks.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Open the door, will ya?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Why don't you quit now, you want out so bad?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Open the door. We're late.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I mean it -- you got enough money now. Head out for California. Surf's up, Jack, and you're digging wells in the snow.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What do you mean I got money? I'm as broke as you.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm sorry for the screw-up. But I couldn't help it it's too late to go trick-or-treating now. I couldn't help it I had to stop at Penny's for the costume. And you were hungry, remember.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Who's fault is it then if it's not yours? You're the one in charge, Daddy.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Look. Those kids are still trick-or- treating. They're still out.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Those are the Hoyts.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I don't care. They're out.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Can't you see... look out there. Nobody's got their porch lights on anymore. It's too late. Those Hoyt kids are just out to get in trouble. See, they put shaving cream all over that mailbox there. They chopped down Herb Crane's new bushes. Little bastards. Jesus H. Christ.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Why do they do that?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Do what?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: You know.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Break stuff?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Yeah. It's stupid.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I guess they're stupid.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Did you do that when you were a kid?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Well, yeah. Sort of. Nothing really mean. Me and my pals, me and my brothers. It was kind of funny then. Stealing pumpkins, soaping windows. Stuff like that.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Was it funny?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: To us it was.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: But it's not funny now.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It's not funny now. I'm a cop and I gotta listen to all the complaints people make. I'm not a kid anymore. You change.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I bet you did lots of bad things.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I just think you used to be bad.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: No. I didn't used to be bad. No sir. Where do you get this stuff? From your mother?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: No. She doesn't talk about you anymore.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Go on, Jill. Some of those kids you still know.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I don't want to.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Why? Why not? You know these kids from when you went to school here. It hasn't been that long.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: It's not that.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What then?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: It's stupid.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It's fun.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I want to go home.  I don't like it here.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Oh, Jesus, come on, will you? Don't mess this up anymore than it's already been messed up. Join the other kids. Do that and before you know it you'll be as happy as a goddamned clam.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Some party, huh? Sorry I lost sight of you. I had to step outside for a smoke. You find anybody you know here? There must be some kids you used to know from school. You want to go tomorrow? See your old teachers? Be more fun than hanging out with me all day.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: No what?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: No I didn't see anybody I know. No I don't want to go to school here tomorrow. I want to go home.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You are home. There are lots of kids you still know here.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I don't want to be here. Don't worry, I love you, Daddy, I do. But I want to go home.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Jesus. Listen, Jill, tell you what. Tomorrow morning, you still want to go home, I'll drive you down. I'll get off work or something.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I called Mommy.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What? You called Mommy? Just now?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Jesus, why?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I... because I want to go home. She said she'd come and get me.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Come and get you! Shit! It's a damn half hour drive each way. Why didn't you talk to me about it first?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: See, I knew you'd be mad.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah. Yeah, right, I'm mad. What'd you tell her, for Christ sake?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I told her I wanted to come home. Daddy, don't be mad at me.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Well, I guess I am. I planned this, I planned all this, you know. I mean, it's sort of pathetic, but I planned it. You shouldn't have called your mother.  C'mon, we're gonna call her before she leaves.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: She's gone already!  Gone already! Couldn't wait.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: That's all you got to say? "Yes".

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: She won't be here for a half hour. Think you can stand it that long?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Where do you expect to wait for her? Obviously downstairs with the other kids isn't good enough.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Sit right there by yourself if you want. Wait for her by yourself. That's fine with me. Just dandy. I'm going downstairs.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: That's fine with me too. When Mommy comes, tell her I'm up here.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Dad.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm glad you're here. Can you stay for a while?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Are we going in this?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah. My car's in the shop. This'll be fine.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: It's pretty old.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It belongs to Pop.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Pop?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Grandpa. My father. It's his.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: How about a Big Mac?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Mommy won't let me eat fast food. You know that. It's bad for you.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: C'mon, we can always sneak a Big Mac. And a cherry turnover. Your favorite. What do you say?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What do you want, then?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You can't have nothing, Jill. We need lunch. Mr. Pizza?

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Same thing, Daddy. Mommy says --

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I know what Mommy says. I'm in charge today, though.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Okay. So we'll get what you want. What do you want?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Nothing, I guess. I guess I can wait till we get home. Maybe we'll stop by Wickham's for a hamburger when we get to Lawford. That suit you? You always like Wickham's.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Please don't cry. Please, honey.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: What are you sorry for?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I don't know. For the food business. I guess. I just thought, you know, we'd sneak a Big Mac on Mommy, like we used to.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I want to go home.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You can't.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: That's illegal, you know.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: You're a policeman.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Nope. Not anymore. I'm nothing anymore.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Jill, please, it's alright. Nothing happened.

turns.speaker: JILL
turns.text: I want to go home.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Okay, let's go home, then.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: We're looking for the funniest costume! And the scariest! And the most imaginative! And the best costume of all!

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Got here just in time. Go ahead. Jump in line. Maybe you'll win a prize.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Tomorrow, Gordon.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Watch this snow. It's coming down tonight.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Told you the snow was coming down. Take the grader.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Where's the plow?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Jimmy took it. Jack's out hunting with Evan Twombley.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: His son-in-law damn near killed me.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: At the school crossing. In his BMW. Coulda hurt some kids. I'm gonna bust his ass.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Don't go playing policeman.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What am I -- a security guard? You hired me, you and your Selectman friends.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: You don't want the extra police pay?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm not saying that.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Get the grader. Go out 29 past Toby's. Don't let Lillian get to you. She didn't belong here. That's why she left.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Fuck you.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: That's what I love about a small town. You know everybody.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: What's the hurry?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: A hunting accident. Jack and Twombley.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I figured you already heard.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Twombley, Jesus. We got to get moving: I got to get up there. How would I know? C'mon, you drive. We'll take my truck.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Fuck. Turn it off.  All you heard was there was some kinda accident?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Twombley's shot. I heard that. Not Jack. He's okay, I assume.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Fuck. You don't know how bad or anything?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You mean Twombley?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Yes, Wade, I mean Twombley. Put out that cigarette. Fuck. Fuck. Fuck.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: He more than likely just shot himself in the foot or something. That's what usually happens.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: I shoulda sent you instead of Jack.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I wish you had. I'd rather be deer hunting instead of freezing my ass on that fucking grader.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: You ain't the hunter Jack is. And he can't drive the grader worth shit.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Like hell.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: That must've been Twombley. Jesus. I bet that was Twombley.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You want me to follow them to Littleton?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Let's get to the top and talk to Jack first. He'll know what happened. He fucking better. If this coulda been avoided, I'll put that kid's ass in a sling.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: What the fuck. My day's already ruined.  Give me the keys. You can go back with Jack. You still got a shitload of plowing to do.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It ain't done, if that's what you mean.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Something bugging you?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah. A few things.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Well, right now we're not too interested. Finish up what you gotta do, then you can get bugged on your own time.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: How you holding up, Wade?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm fine, fine.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: You Rolfe?  I remember you from high school. You're a teacher now? Harvard?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Sorry about the long lunch. My clutch is going out again.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: You ever think of getting a new car, Wade?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: On what you pay me?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Elaine! Call Chub Meritt and have him pick up Wade's car, fix the clutch.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: What do I have to do for it?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Nothing, Wade, I've been thinking. You don't get enough appreciation around here and it's time we changed things a little.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I saw Mel Gordon in here this morning.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: He say anything about the summons I tried to give him? Sonofabitch wouldn't accept it.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Wade, that wasn't smart. Going out right after the man's father-in-law shot himself. Let it go. Call it a favor to me.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You? Why?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Mel's doing some business with me. It's nice to do favors for people you do business with. He was in a hurry. No big deal.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: That was before Twombley was shot. Before he knew.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: What's the difference? Take my truck, take a rest -- stop worrying about Mel Gordon. Have you decided what to do with your old man's place -- he going to stay there?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Want to buy?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Don't light that in here. I'm allergic.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I won't. You interested?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You and Mel Gordon?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Could be.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Always count on old Wade for a good screwing. Why should I always pay more, sell cheap? Why should you guys make all the money. You and Mel and Jack. Right's right.

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: Wade, you're done.  Let me have the shop keys.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You two, don't you get it? He's using you. You're his slaves.  Jesus Christ, Jack, don't you see that?

turns.speaker: LARIVIERE
turns.text: The key, Wade.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah, you can have the key. It's the key that's kept me locked to you all these years. I give it to you with pleasure.  Now I'm free. See how easy it is, Jack? All you got to do is give back what the man gave you, and you're free of him.  I've got to call my brother.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Lillian!

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: Where's Jill?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Me and Jill, we just had a little spat. She felt kind of left out, I guess, from not knowing some of the new kids --

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: Where is she now? Is she in the truck with your friends?

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: While you went off for a few beers with your friends? Is that Hettie Rodgers there, with whatzizname?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: She's grown up some, hasn't she?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Oh, Jesus, lay off, will you? It looks like you've won this fucking round already, so lay off a little, for Christ's sake.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I don't want her to go, Lillian.

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: Don't cause a scene. No one's trying to win any 'rounds'. Don't make it any worse.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm not making it any worse. You are. Me and Jill could've worked this thing out. It's normal, it's even normal for me to get a little touchy about it. Believe it or not. How do you think this makes me look, treating her like some tragic victim or something?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You ever come to your father's grave anymore?

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: No, not anymore. It's too... it's too far.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: We should talk.

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: We've done all our talking, Wade.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It's just...

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: Let the past be.  I'm sorry about your mother. I liked her. You never know how much women like that suffer. It's like they live their lives with the sound turned off -- and then they're gone.

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: Wait there. She'll be right out.  Is there snow on the ground up in Lawford?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah, lots.

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: See. Get your boots.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Hi honey.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: No problem. Look, I...

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: You make me sick. I can't believe you've sunk so low.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Low as what? What have I done? It's bad to want to see your own daughter?

turns.speaker: LILLIAN
turns.text: You know what I'm talking about. For what you're doing to me and to the child you say you love so much. Love. You won't get away with it.

turns.speaker: LUGENE
turns.text: Are you okay, Wade? What was wrong? Why were you holding everyone up?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Did you see that sonofabitch in the BMW? He could've killed somebody.

turns.speaker: LUGENE
turns.text: Did you get his number?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I know who it is.

turns.speaker: LUGENE
turns.text: Good. Who?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Mel Gordon.

turns.speaker: LUGENE
turns.text: I still don't understand --

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: From Boston. Evan Twombley's son-in- law -- he was driving. I know where they're headed. Up the lake, Agaway. The old man's out deer hunting with Jack Hewitt, so they probably got some big weekend party planned.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: New hat?  Jill's up, I see.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: For a while.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: How's she doing?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Okay. She's fine.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You two want to do anything tomorrow and need a third party, give me a call, okay? I'm off.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Don't worry. I can protect my virtue. I mean, c'mon, Wade, give me a break.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: See you tomorrow, maybe.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: I'm sorry about what I said.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Said what?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: About you and Jill and needing a third person. She went back to Lillian?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Forget it.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm going to start one of those custody suits. I don't give a fucking shit. You know?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You don't mean that.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah. I mean that.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: No you don't. You're pissed, that's all. You ought to cool off for a few days then have a long talk with Lillian. You know? Work it out with her, tell her how you feel. Lillian's not out to get you.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: The hell she isn't. Lillian's been trying to nail me to a cross since the day I met her. I'm gonna hire me a fucking lawyer from Concord and get this thing, this divorce thing, rearranged. I've been thinking about it a lot. It's like she owns Jill or something. Nobody owns nobody, especially not kids. And I pay her.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Call me.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Tonight. Let's get together.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Jack's sort of sensitive, I guess. More than most. But he'll be okay in a few weeks.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: There's something funny about that shooting. There's lots funny about it, actually.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: I heard he was drunk at Toby's last night and got in a fight with Hettie. He drove off without her...

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm sure, I'm positive it didn't happen the way Jack says it did.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: ...Jack's turned into one of those men who are permanently angry. He used to be a sweet kid, but it's like, when he found out he couldn't play ball anymore, he changed. Now he's like everyone else.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I've been wondering if maybe Jack shot Twombley, instead of Twombley shooting himself. I've been wondering maybe Jack shot him on purpose.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Wade! How can you even think such a thing? Why would Jack Hewitt do that, shoot Twombley on purpose?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Money.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Jack doesn't need money.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Everybody needs money. Except guys like Twombley and that sonofabitch son-in-law of his. People like that.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Jack wouldn't kill for it. Besides, who would pay him?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Lots of people. Guy like Evan Twombley, Boston union official, probably got lots of people want to see him dead. The Government's been investigating his links with the Mafia.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: The Mafia hire Jack Hewitt?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: No, I just know Jack's lying about what happened. He just seemed -- I know that kid, what he's like inside. He's a lot like I was at his age.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You wouldn't have done anything like that, shot someone for money.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: No. Not for money. But, if somebody'd given me half a damned excuse -- I was pretty fucked up, you know.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: But not now.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I can see what you looked like as a kid.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You knew me as a kid.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yeah, but never what you looked like. Not really. Never really studied your face, like now. I was never able to see you as a kid when you were a kid until now, this way.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: What way?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: After making love. I like it. It's nice to see that in a grown-up person.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: It's nice.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Don't you think, do you still think it's a good idea to press this custody thing -- just now?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm her father -- supposed to be, but I'm not able to. Yes. Yes, I am. It may be the only thing in my life I've been so clear about wanting. Even if it takes a big fight.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Then... I guess you have to.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: There's another thing I've been thinking about. I don't know how you feel about the idea, Margie, because we've never talked about it. But I've been thinking lately, I've been thinking we should get married sometime. You and me.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Oh, Wade.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I've been thinking about it, that's all.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You've been married twice --

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It was to the same woman. I was just a kid...  It's not like a marriage proposal or anything, just a thought. Something for you and me to talk about and think about. You know?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Alright. I'll think about it.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Did you tell them?  That we were coming?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Don't you think it's proper for a fella to introduce his girl to his parents?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: I know your parents.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I just want to pick up my divorce papers. For the lawyer. It won't take long.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Are you sure they're home? Did you call?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: The truck's here. Looks like they've stayed inside since the snow started.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Strange.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Think they're alright?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Of course! I would've heard.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I don't know for Christ's sake!

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: This is nuts.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Wade.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Jesus Christ, Pop, let's go home. I got waylaid. Sorry.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: What on earth is happening to you? Why are you acting this way?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It's my tooth! My fucking tooth! I can't even think anymore because of it.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: I heard you talking. You got fired this morning, didn't you?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Look, that's temporary, believe me. There's so much shit gonna hit the fan the next few days, my getting fired by LaRiviere and Merritt won't matter a bit.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Going somewhere, Margie?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: I'm just cleaning out some of this stuff that's built up. For the rummage sale. And some things for the cleaners. And the laundromat.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Don't lie to me. You're leaving me, I can see that.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Don't be silly. Hi, Jill.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Have you been heating the house? Not just with the stove.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: There's a furnace.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You're not using it today?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: It's broke I guess. There's an electric in the bedroom.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Maybe Wade should take a look at it. Your pipes'll freeze.  Wade, would you do that?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Coffee's perked.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: When did she die?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Is...? She's dead then?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: It makes me sad.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Can --?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Makes me sad it was her. Instead of me. I shoulda froze.

turns.speaker: MEL GORDON
turns.text: Whitehouse. Next time, phone ahead.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: MEL GORDON
turns.text: I said, 'Next time, phone ahead.'

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Jesus Christ. Mr. Gordon, when I come all the way to serve somebody a summons, I don't call ahead for an appointment.

turns.speaker: MEL GORDON
turns.text: What the hell are you talking about?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm issuing you a ticket. Moving violation.

turns.speaker: MEL GORDON
turns.text: Moving violation! I just got out of bed and you're telling me you're giving me a goddamn speeding ticket? Now? Are you nuts? Is that it, Whitehouse? You're nuts?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yesterday morning, you passed a stopped school bus, which was flashing its lights, then you--

turns.speaker: MEL GORDON
turns.text: Hold on!

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Don't ever put your hands on me, Mr. Gordon.

turns.speaker: MEL GORDON
turns.text: You're talking about a goddamned ticket, from when I passed you at the school where you were deciding to hold up traffic while dreaming of becoming a traffic cop or something?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Don't give me a hard time, Mr. Gordon. I'm just --

turns.speaker: MEL GORDON
turns.text: Doing your fucking job. I know. I watch television too.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Yes. Here's your ticket.

turns.speaker: MEL GORDON
turns.text: You get the hell out of my house now, asshole. And know this -- you are going to be a lucky asshole if I haven't got you fired before the day is out. I can do it with one phone call, and I'm pissed enough to do it now!

turns.speaker: MRS. GORDON
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I was... I'm Wade Whitehouse. I was wondering, is your husband here?

turns.speaker: MRS. GORDON
turns.text: He's asleep. We were up very late.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Well, yes, I'm... I want to say that I'm real sorry about your father, Mrs. Twombley.

turns.speaker: MRS. GORDON
turns.text: Mrs. Gordon. Thank you.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Well, yeah, I suppose. Sure. I just had a little business to settle with Mr. Gordon. I'm the local police officer.

turns.speaker: MRS. GORDON
turns.text: Something about my father?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Oh, no. No, it's a... it's a traffic thing. No big deal.

turns.speaker: MRS. GORDON
turns.text: Can't it wait, then?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Take care, Wade.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: You be careful of that little bastard. He's dying to get in your pants, you know.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: It don't look right.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: The sign. It looks like it's spelled wrong or something.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Fuck. Wade Whitehouse. It's people like you that keep this fucking town from prospering. Whatever somebody does to improve things around here, you gotta find fault with it.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: I'm not finding fault. It's a good idea, good for you, good for the town. Real modern too.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: This town sucks.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Aw, c'mon, I was only saying there's something wrong with "Home Made Cooking", that's all. The sign's fine. What it says is wrong.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Marg!

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: That goddamned woman. Thinks she can cart Jill off and leave me alone like this. I'm more than pissed, Margie. I'm a whole lot more than pissed. I been that plenty and I know the difference. This is different.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Marg! You got orders!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You talked to Jack?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Not since last night. He took a guy hunting.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: The fucker shot himself. Ker-bang! That's what it sounds like. Not on purpose. I assume accidental.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Jack?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: The other guy.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Where... how'd you hear that?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: CB. Little while ago. One of the boys on the way in picked up Jack on the CB calling for state troopers. I figured you'd know what really happened. The fucking guy kill himself? This Twombley, who the fuck is he, anyhow?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: No, I... I've been out on the grader all morning. Twombley's summer people. Massachusetts. Friend of Gordon's. It was his idea for Jack to take him hunting.  I gotta go.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Jillie, you want a cheese grilled sandwich?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's called a grilled cheese sandwich, you dub.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Wade, I got a message for you.  Jack Hewitt, he's looking for you. Wants you to clear your stuff out of his office in Town Hall.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: His office. You mean my old office.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Well, I guess -- that's what he said.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: He got his deer yet?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No, he's out now. Somewhere on the mountain. I'd stay away from him if I were you. He's real pissed.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Rolfe.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: A lesson in work and its rewards. You'll thank me for this one day.  Sally, turn off that TV!

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Just do it.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Atta-go.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: What was that?  You got something to say, say it! Say it!

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: You no-good pup!
